summary: This is a memorandum and order by Judge Loretta A. Preska denying Alan Dershowitz's request to modify a protective order from the Giuffre v. Maxwell case to gain access to its discovery materials for his defense in the Giuffre v. Dershowitz defamation case. The court also orders Cooper & Kirk, Giuffre's new counsel, to destroy Maxwell case materials in their possession, as their possession violates the protective order.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz
persons.role: Defendant in defamation case, Plaintiff requesting modification
persons.context: Harvard law professor and attorney who is a defendant in a defamation lawsuit brought by Virginia Giuffre. He requests modification of a protective order to access discovery from the separate Giuffre v. Maxwell case for his defense.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the settled civil case Giuffre v. Maxwell. The protective order from that case is the subject of the current dispute.

persons.name: Virginia Giuffre
persons.role: Plaintiff in defamation case against Dershowitz and settled case against Maxwell
persons.context: The plaintiff in both the defamation case against Alan Dershowitz and the previously settled civil case against Ghislaine Maxwell. Her allegations connect both cases.

persons.name: Loretta A. Preska
persons.context: The judge authoring this memorandum and order, ruling on Dershowitz's request and the issue of Cooper & Kirk's possession of materials.

persons.name: Robert W. Sweet
persons.context: The judge who entered the original protective order in the Giuffre v. Maxwell case in 2016.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Deceased financier, central figure in sex-trafficking allegations
persons.context: Mentioned as the central figure in the sex-trafficking scheme that both Ghislaine Maxwell and Alan Dershowitz are alleged to have been involved with.

connections.description: Giuffre is suing Dershowitz for defamation, alleging he falsely denied her claim that she was forced to have intercourse with him as an underage victim of Epstein's scheme.
Giuffre was the plaintiff in a settled civil case against Maxwell, alleging Maxwell was a ringleader in Epstein's sex-trafficking scheme.
Described in the document as Epstein's 'trusted lieutenant' who facilitated his alleged sex-trafficking scheme.
Dershowitz is described as being in 'Epstein's substantial orbit,' and Giuffre alleges he was one of the prominent individuals who took advantage of the trafficking scheme.
Cooper & Kirk is the law firm retained by Virginia Giuffre to represent her in the Dershowitz case and, purportedly, in conjunction with the Maxwell case.

events.title: Maxwell Protective Order Entered
events.description: Judge Robert W. Sweet enters a protective order in Giuffre v. Maxwell to govern confidential discovery materials.

events.title: Oral Argument on Modification Request
events.description: The court holds oral argument on Alan Dershowitz's request to modify the Maxwell protective order.

events.title: Court Denies Modification and Orders Destruction of Materials
events.description: Judge Preska issues this order denying Dershowitz's request to modify the protective order and orders Cooper & Kirk to destroy Maxwell case materials in their possession.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York
keyFacts: Alan Dershowitz's request for full access to all discovery from the settled Giuffre v. Maxwell case to aid his defense in the Giuffre v. Dershowitz defamation case was denied by the court.
The court found that Giuffre's new law firm, Cooper & Kirk, improperly possessed the Maxwell case materials in violation of the protective order and ordered them destroyed.
The court ruled that Dershowitz failed to show the 'extraordinary circumstance or compelling need' required to modify a protective order that parties had relied upon.
The document explicitly connects the two civil cases, stating Giuffre's suit against Maxwell alleged a sex-trafficking scheme, while her suit against Dershowitz alleges he was a participant.
The court expressed concern that granting Dershowitz access could undermine a separate, careful unsealing process underway in the Maxwell case and risk public leakage of sealed materials.
